summary: A personal memoir recording covering family memories and life stories.

stories.title: Introduction to the Recording Project
stories.description: Lindy explains the purpose of the recording, acknowledging potential errors and outlining his plan to recount his life's highlights.

stories.title: The Move to Canada in 1920
stories.description: Lindy recalls moving to Canada in 1920 when he was eight years old, mentioning a detail about a bridge costing $25 a year.

stories.title: Helping Laurie with the Oat Harvest
stories.description: Lindy recounts helping a man named Laurie harvest his oats after he was overwhelmed, involving several neighbors and taking a few days to complete.; Lindy describes the extreme heat he experienced while helping his cousin with the harvest in Nebraska, an experience he claims was unmatched anywhere else.

stories.title: Janie's New Baby and Sudden Departure
stories.description: Lindy mentions a woman named Janie who had a new baby and then unexpectedly left, repeating 'She's gone' multiple times.

stories.title: Thrashing in Frederick and the Two-Month Journey
stories.description: Lindy discusses the 35 days spent thrashing in Frederick, noting that the overall journey took approximately two months.; Initial work and travel north, then to Minot.; Seeking and almost accepting a job with a power company.

stories.title: Lindy's Initial Job and Wage
stories.description: Lindy recounts starting a new job and being paid 79 cents an hour, highlighting her expertise as she was able to 'cut the mustard'.

stories.title: The Flying Squad and Extensive Travel
stories.description: Lindy describes a period of extensive travel, visiting Canberra, Portland, and locations east and west, as part of a 'flying squad' covering approximately 150 miles of line.

stories.title: Immigration Status and Unexpected Work
stories.description: Lindy recalls an incident where an immigration official unexpectedly offered her work, revealing she was a Canadian and would be working for them.; Lindy details a process of inventorying machinery and paying for it as they went, requiring her to leave the tape recording to return.

stories.title: Tape Organization and Chronological Order
stories.description: Lindy explains her efforts to organize the tapes chronologically, referencing a specific tape she shared with someone named Joe and acknowledging the difficulty of remembering details accurately over time.; Lindy expresses her intention to review past recordings and experiences, recognizing that it has been a long time since she performed certain tasks and acknowledging the challenges of recalling details.

stories.title: Lindy Acquires Dyer's Plant Management
stories.description: This story details Lindy's negotiation with Jack Dyer to take over the diesel plant, involving a deal where Lindy assumed Dyer's debts and provided a car and cash in exchange for ownership.

stories.title: Lindy's Reflections on a Man's Depression
stories.description: Lindy reflects on a man she knew and wonders about his depression, expressing confusion and a sense of guilt about her interactions with him.; Lindy briefly mentions the experience of contracting, setting the stage for a later, more detailed explanation.

stories.title: Lindy's Recording Process and Erasure
stories.description: Lindy describes the process of recording her memoirs over five years, noting that the tapes were sometimes erased by her children.

stories.title: Lindy's Career in Contracting (1927-1945)
stories.description: Lindy recounts her career in contracting, spanning from 1927 to 1945, highlighting her experience in handling men and the challenges of labor relations.

stories.title: Lindy's Approach to Labor Problems
stories.description: Lindy details her strategy for dealing with difficult employees, emphasizing the importance of moving forward and not dwelling on past issues.; Lindy describes the beginning of her building career, noting her initial lack of equipment and her subsequent purchase of a half-ton truck from a dealer in Estevan.

stories.title: Acquiring the Half-Ton Truck in Estevan
stories.description: Lindy recounts his experience buying a dilapidated half-ton truck from a dealer in Estevan, securing it despite its poor condition and limited availability.

stories.title: Revamping Military Trucks with Lindy's Brother
stories.description: Lindy and his brother collaborated, using welding and cutting torches at a garage in Midale, to revamp acquired military trucks.

stories.title: Dismantling Airports and Uncovering Buried Cable
stories.description: Lindy describes the challenging task of dismantling airports, specifically the difficulty of uncovering miles of buried cable without causing damage.

stories.title: Bidding on the Power Line Project
stories.description: Lindy reflects on the surprisingly close bids received for a power line project, noting his bid was the lowest of four within a narrow margin.

stories.title: Working Through Frost in Saskatoon
stories.description: Lindy details the experience of working in Saskatoon during winter, where he had to burn frost out of the ground due to the frozen conditions.; Lindy describes a short job in Davidson for Dominion Electric before a period of downtime in Estevan.

stories.title: Wavering to Radville
stories.description: Construction of a line and subsequent farm work.; Building a large high-voltage line and the challenges involved.

stories.title: Recruiting Uneducated but Reliable Labor
stories.description: Lindy describes hiring a man who was older, uneducated, and couldn't write his name, but proved to be a good, honest worker.

stories.title: The Winnipeg Pulley Purchase
stories.description: Lindy recounts his trip to Winnipeg, Ashdown Hardware, and his surprising purchase of 250 wooden pulleys after the hardware store clerk initially claimed they didn't have any.

stories.title: Weather & Job Details
stories.description: Initial comments on a trade discussion; Weather conditions and early job recollections

stories.title: Family Reunion
stories.description: Account of a family reunion and related events

stories.title: Building the Line from Kenora to Norquay
stories.description: Lindy recounts the challenge of building a power line between Kenora and Norquay, Saskatchewan, and the deal he made with Ted Durnan to secure a boring machine.

stories.title: Dealing with Jack Gardner's Management Style
stories.description: Lindy describes his experience with Jack Gardner, a capable but easily overwhelmed foreman, and his attempt to manage his productivity.

stories.title: The Sunday Crew Incident
stories.description: Lindy shares a humorous anecdote about a crew's refusal to work on a Sunday, leading to a confrontation and a delayed payday.

stories.title: The Oxbow Farm Project
stories.description: Lindy describes a successful season in 1948, including the completion of a large project connecting 200 farms near Oxbow.; Describes work in Regina and a subsequent contract for equipment rental.; Details of early contracting jobs and travel

stories.title: Early Farm Electrification and Bidding
stories.description: Lindy describes the early days of farm electrification, the established pricing system for poles and transformers, and how it covered all aspects of the job.

stories.title: The Potash Mine Work
stories.description: Lindy recounts the work his company did for the Kalium potash mine, including both construction and design assistance due to a lack of in-house expertise.; Lindy recounts a large, $125,000 (and growing) project at Swift College, highlighting the unexpected costs and challenges.

stories.title: The Rainy Season and Remote Camp
stories.description: Lindy describes a difficult situation involving relentless rain, difficulty getting workers, and the establishment of a remote camp with cooking facilities.

stories.title: Analyzing the Job's Profitability
stories.description: Lindy instructs Art to meticulously review the expenses of the Swift College project, revealing a surprisingly low 6% net profit despite the challenges.

stories.title: Lindy's Retirement and the Sale of Achen Construction
stories.description: Lindy details his decision to retire, selling the company to Art, Bill, George, and Vaughn, and establishing Achen sixty-five Exercise ieuxProsperity Concerns Limited.; Lindy notes the continued success of the company after his departure, highlighting its consistent employment and profitability.

stories.title: Lindy's Perspective on the Changing Construction Landscape
stories.description: Lindy explains his belief that contractors would thrive due to union pressures and his own experience of burnout, leading to his decision to retire.

stories.title: Employee Loyalty and Reflections
stories.description: Lindy reminisces about long-term employees like Ernie Smith and George Jenny, and their positive experiences working for Achen Construction.

stories.title: Tragic Events and Company Transitions
stories.description: Lindy mentions the deaths of Ron Kennedy and Bill Zaharachuk, and the subsequent changes in ownership and partnerships within the company.

stories.title: Lindy's Experience with Multiple Foremen
stories.description: Lindy recounts learning valuable lessons from the five or six different foremen he worked under during his time with various companies.

stories.title: Lindy's Approach to Management - First Names
stories.description: Lindy describes his philosophy of using first names with his employees to foster a positive working relationship and increase production.

stories.title: Lindy's Career Progression - From Digging Holes to Hotline
stories.description: Lindy details his career path, starting with manual labor and progressing to becoming a professional 'hotline' lineman, demonstrating his versatility and skill.

stories.title: Lindy's Estevan Education
stories.description: Lindy reflects on his time in Estevan as a period of significant learning and experience, where he handled a wide range of tasks and gained expertise in various areas.; Lindy highlights his unique experience of rewinding and repairing transformers, a skill uncommon among his peers.

stories.title: Lindy's Steam Plant Knowledge
stories.description: Lindy describes his acquired knowledge of steam plants, gained through assisting and learning from them during his time in Estevan.; Lindy recounts operating a diesel plant and explains his understanding of its mechanics, even with a small, single-cylinder engine.

stories.title: Lindy's Calibration Skills
stories.description: Lindy details his ability to calibrate meters and switchboard instruments, showcasing his technical expertise in power plant operations.

stories.title: Lindy's Customer Relationships in Estevan
stories.description: Lindy emphasizes his strong personal relationships with his 1,200 customers in Estevan, highlighting the importance of customer interaction in his role.; Lindy describes his extensive knowledge of mining, both underground and strip mining, gained from serving the field for seven years.; Lindy recounts the demanding nature of his on-call schedule, emphasizing his pride in his work ethic and commitment to responding to emergencies.

stories.title: Lindy's Early Wiring Work in Midale
stories.description: Lindy recalls his early experience with inside wiring in 1931 when he built the power system for the village of Midale.; Lindy recounts being encouraged by a wiring inspector to take the journeyman's exam and his subsequent joy upon receiving the certification, which he still possesses.

stories.title: Lindy's Specialized Electrical Knowledge
stories.description: Lindy describes his deep understanding of electrical principles, despite not performing extensive wiring work, and the value of holding a journeyman's paper.; Lindy explains how Art Miller's company keeps him on retainer due to his journeyman's paper, ensuring he's available for specialized electrical needs.; Lindy explains the legal requirement for a journeyman electrician on certain job sites and how his status allows him to be available for those situations.

stories.title: Lindy's Understanding of Electrical Layouts
stories.description: Lindy highlights his ability to quickly understand electrical layouts, contrasting it with the confusion experienced by laypeople.; Lindy admits his lack of expertise in areas like tape recorders and telephones, clarifying his specialization in electricity generation and distribution.

stories.title: Lindy's Career Longevity and Recognition
stories.description: Lindy reflects on his long career in Saskatchewan and his status as one of the few remaining experienced electricians of his generation.

stories.title: The Importance of Service in Electrical Work
stories.description: Lindy emphasizes the importance of service in the electrical business, recalling a former employee's appreciation for the comprehensive knowledge gained working for him.; Lindy shares the story of George Jenny, a former employee who gained valuable experience and eventually used his savings to buy a farm and semi-retire.

stories.title: Lindy's Early Wage and Room & Board in Worthington, Iowa
stories.description: Lindy recounts earning 35 cents an hour while working in Worthington, Iowa, covering his own room and board and driving a Model T Ford.; A foreman recognized Lindy's work ethic and, despite a denial from headquarters, secretly boosted his hourly wage to 40 cents.

stories.title: Lindy's Departure as a Lineman
stories.description: Lindy briefly worked as a lineman before leaving after only a month.; Lindy left his job and went to work for his sick brother, Laurie, in Sioux Falls, South Dakota.; Lindy started as a second-class lineman in Aberdeen, South Dakota, earning 45 cents an hour.

stories.title: Lindy's Experience with Multiple Foremen
stories.description: Lindy describes working under three different foremen, one of whom died, one was transferred, and the third mentored him in hotline work.; A foreman taught Lindy about hotline work and the importance of safety precautions like wearing rubber gloves.

stories.title: Wage Progression and Room & Board Costs
stories.description: Lindy details his wage increases and the associated cost of room and board as he moved to Kenmer, North Dakota, and Canada.

stories.title: Lindy's Early Wages and Living Expenses
stories.description: Lindy reflects on his wages in the early 1930s and how affordable room and board was at the time, sometimes including laundry services.

stories.title: Lindy's Power Plant Position
stories.description: Lindy describes his time operating a power plant and the subsequent wage he received.

stories.title: Lindy's First Wage Increase After Marriage
stories.description: Lindy recounts receiving a series of $10 monthly raises after getting married.

stories.title: Lindy's Contracting and Income
stories.description: Lindy explains his income while contracting, noting that he didn't take a steady wage but lived comfortably on around $300 a month.; After incorporating his business, Lindy sought advice from auditors who recommended a salary of $1,000 a month.

stories.title: Lindy's Consistent Salary During Contracting
stories.description: Lindy maintained a salary of $1,000 a month for 12 years (1953-1965) while taking end-of-year bonuses.
